ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Energy as a land area metric, electricity market design, and the structure of NDCS and net-zero pledges
great survey courses on different forms of energy and the current trajectory of the world on meeting net zero goals
I learned the basics of the energy industry and climate change.
I learned about the state of the energy transition today, geoscience, the Paris accords, carbon pricing, emissions, and various countries' and institutions' towards decarbonization.
An overview of energy and the role it plays in our world.
I learned about energy mixes and how economics and renewable energy go hand in hand in our current world.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: this class is a great, relaxed way to learn about world energy. It's definitely a get-out-what-you-put-in sort of class. There are only a few readings assigned each week and it is not a high pressure environment, but if you're genuinely interested in the subject material you will enjoy class discussions.
such a laidback course but still is worthwhile -- low workload but I still got a lot out of it
Strengths: guest speakers, wonderful professor, engaging work, interesting topics and fun projects

I really liked how this course covered a variety of energy topics from different angles, including policy, technology, and economics. I also really enjoyed the different formats of learning like the simulated energy auction, debate, and presentations. The only thing I would improve relates to readings -- some of the assigned papers were hundreds of pages long, which was just unrealistic to complete. I would have liked for us to have been assigned excerpts of reports and/or be given more guidance in completing the reading homework generally.

This course would be best advertised as a junior or senior seminar. Each class is a mixture of lecture and discussion, but in order to contribute meaningfully to the discussion, a significant background knowledge in energy is required. With that said, however, it is not difficult to do well in the course even with limited background knowledge. Professor Oristaglio is a very knowledgeable and understanding professor.
Strength - the seminar format allowed discussions between students. I enjoyed the type of assessments. They were engaging and thoughtful.

Strengths: content and activities
Weaknesses: time the course is offered (Friday mornings aren't ideal)

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if you need the energy studies credit. It's a good fourth or fifth class, but don't expect to walk away with a novel vision of world energy.
yes!! great fifth class
Absolutely, it is a felxible and fun course to take that provides a good introduction into the energy industry.

Yes! This class is basically Energy Studies 101. Everyone in the course (students and professor included) is very passionate about the subject matter, we cover many different topics, and it's a chill seminar where you still learn a lot.
Yes if you are completing the energy studies certificate. As its title suggests, the topics discussed are very multidisciplinary and thus provide a valuable insight into the world of energy studies.

Yes, great class to take for energy studies. Very light workload, but you get a lot out of it. It's so refreshing to work on projects, essays and presentations without the stress of grading or with time pressure. I found myself enjoying the assignments in this class a lot more because I didn't feel like I was doing them just because they're assigned. Every assignment draws from the real world (energy markets, Paris climate agreement, geoengineering etc.) and the knowledge you acquire is very practical.
Yes! This course was a great course that viewed world energy. I really enjoyed the activities and assignments.
